results.content:
I went into this course, I think, expecting a little more depth. This was very much a basic, high level, overview of HTML, CSS, and Javascript with some examples that at times felt like they lacked context and clarity. Some items were simply presented without any explanation as to their function, purpose, or fundamental principles.

The closing functionality of the modal example presented in the last Javascript section also did not appear to work, nor was it addressed by the instructor.  

This would be a good intro course for someone with previous programming background, but may not benefit those with little to no prior experience, and who are looking to get started. 

I felt the instructor was easy to understand and had a relatively consistent flow throughout the course. I think the instructor was only limited by the content.

results.content:
The instructor's voice was very pleasant and his speaking style was very easy to understand.  

Unfortunately, when transitioning from one video to the next, he did not always show the complete code changes so we would know what exactly needed to be changed in our own code to follow along.  

There were often times when we were being told what to type in without the instructor explaining WHY we were including certain lines of code.  

Much to my disappointment, the final source code used by the instructor was never made available for download, and there was never any clear part in the final video that showed all parts of the code for all three files, so in the end, when my Open Modal code resulted in TypeError: btn is null, unfortunately I had nothing to compare to in order to see if I could find my mistake.  I did exhaustively replay the video and pause where possible to compare what I could, to no avail.

results.content: Organization is poor, communication is just OK, lectures 3-8 were not put together well at all - they came with no segue and were straight out of the blue. Kinda like a kid with ADD or ADHD who's focused on something them gets distracted by something totally unrelated. Then the website didn't work, either. The resources supplied were for lectures 3-8 and covered nothing else. I would not recommend this course.

results.content: I was able to follow along for some of the course, but the section with the tutorials from W3schools were horrible. The instructor in those videos pauses too long when she is speaking, gives vague explanations on what everything is doing, and goes far too fast (as she is just copying and pasting code, you cannot pause quickly enough to even write the code down yourself). The rest of the lectures were okay, but the final two lectures on how to do a Modal felt rushed.

results.content:
Really clear teaching with American instructor.  It is a short course which is great if you haven't touched JavaScript yet.  In 2 hours you'll build a simple project where you will code HTML, CSS and JS.  So if you've been putting JavaScript off until you are "ready" just get your feet wet with this course.

It's a short course so you won't always be coding along, sometimes the instructor will build a feature and explain it in the lesson.  You will get to catch up - but this is more of an overview as to what's possible with HTML, CSS and JavaScript.

Don't worry if you don't understand the animation code as you would use generators for this.  The JavaScript functions are quite clear but you will need learn a bit theory more online.

Overall a really useful introduction to front end web development covering a lot of the basics.
results.content_html:

Don't worry if you don't understand the animation code as you would use generators for this. The JavaScript functions are quite clear but you will need learn a bit theory more online.

Overall a really useful introduction to front end web development covering a lot of the basics.

results.content:
The HTML part was excellent and the basic css, however simple, was presented adequately.

In later videos the instructor would have added or removed code in between videos to show more examples, and I feel for a beginner course jumping around like that without showing them you coding it may be jarring to inexperienced viewers.

When he went over "responsive design", he never mentioned using "@media" in css to target smaller / larger resolutions. (Though I'm not sure if this is due to the course being old, him not wanting to overload new coders, or simply forgetting.)

The JavaScript portion of the video was a tad odd, both in the implementation, and what he chose to show as an example. I feel something instructional about how the basic syntax works would've been more helpful to beginners, instead of giving them an arbitrary use case example.

The course felt a bit dated (doesn't use  JavaScript ES6, no @media etc), but overall it is a decent supplementary course for people with little to no experience in HTML, and maybe CSS, however I would not recommend this for learning JavaScript.

results.content:
As an introductory course, this is excellent. If you have little experience with web development, you will need more training or just practice to continue to increase your skills...because this is an intro. Don't expect to come out an expert. 

The instructor was clear and experienced. The pace was slow enough that you could keep up and practice the same coding as he went along AND you could see your web page develoop, too. It was especially helpful to see the use of Mozilla Thimble for the mobile page sizing. Well done! I enjoyed this course and recommend it to others.
